ticket.title: ActiveResource time changed
ticket.original-body:
It's like described in WhyNotWiki: You have an ActiveRecord model with a date attibute. When calling the show action in the controller in format xml, the dates shows up correctly.
But when you have a service that uses ActiveResource to get you model, the time is 2 hours before the one you entered.
For a workaround I tried to generate a Time.gm(..., (old_time.hour+2), ...) but that doesn't handle hours past 22 (raises an ArgumentError (out of range).
ticket.latest-body:
It's like described in WhyNotWiki: You have an ActiveRecord model with a date attibute. When calling the show action in the controller in format xml, the dates shows up correctly.
But when you have a service that uses ActiveResource to get you model, the time is 2 hours before the one you entered.
For a workaround I tried to generate a Time.gm(..., (old_time.hour+2), ...) but that doesn't handle hours past 22 (raises an ArgumentError (out of range).
ticket.original-body-html:
It's like described in WhyNotWiki: You have an ActiveRecord model with a date attibute. When calling the show action in the controller in format xml, the dates shows up correctly.

But when you have a service that uses ActiveResource to get you model, the time is 2 hours before the one you entered.

For a workaround I tried to generate a Time.gm(..., (old_time.hour+2), ...) but that doesn't handle hours past 22 (raises an ArgumentError (out of range).

version.title: ActiveResource time changed

version.body: Oh, ok, I just saw that adding hours is done by old_time+2.hours Ok, but the bug remains...
version.body-html: Oh, ok, I just saw that adding hours is done by old_time+2.hours Ok, but the bug remains...
version.title: ActiveResource time changed

version.body:
Ideally, you'd be able to pull together a failing test case to prove this. Second best would be some script/console output that shows the issue.
Also let us know which version of Rails you're using, and, if you're setting config.time_zone, what that's set to. Thanks.
version.body-html:
Ideally, you'd be able to pull together a failing test case to prove this. Second best would be some script/console output that shows the issue.

Also let us know which version of Rails you're using, and, if you're setting config.time_zone, what that's set to. Thanks.
version.title: ActiveResource time changed

version.body: Ok, I built two RoR Applications (Producer and Consumer). And now I'm uploading both of them in one ZIP (Testcase-942.zip). Try the XML Output, you'll see two different times in the created-at attribute. Sorry if that's the wrong way but it's my first bug report.
version.body-html: Ok, I built two RoR Applications (Producer and Consumer). And now I'm uploading both of them in one ZIP (Testcase-942.zip). Try the XML Output, you'll see two different times in the created-at attribute. Sorry if that's the wrong way but it's my first bug report.
version.title: ActiveResource time changed

version.body:
To add to my workaround: First I added the 2hours in a method in controllers/application.rb which, of course, is wrong. Those 2h should be added in the model resulting in a line like def start attributes["start"] = attributes["start"] + 2.hours end
where start is the attribute of type Time.
Oh yes, I' using Rail 2.0.2
version.body-html:
To add to my workaround: First I added the 2hours in a method in controllers/application.rb which, of course, is wrong. Those 2h should be added in the model resulting in a line like def start attributes["start"] = attributes["start"] + 2.hours end

where start is the attribute of type Time.

Oh yes, I' using Rail 2.0.2
version.title: ActiveResource time changed

version.body: Hm, ok, I just deployed my app to the server and realized there is NO time-shifting. A friend suggested to look at the timezones and, really, there is the difference: My dev-system displays in its XML sth like 2008-09-06T17:45:08+02:00 where my production system displays 2008-09-10T11:28:29+00:00 (mind the +00:00 and +02:00 at the end).
version.body-html: Hm, ok, I just deployed my app to the server and realized there is NO time-shifting. A friend suggested to look at the timezones and, really, there is the difference: My dev-system displays in its XML sth like 2008-09-06T17:45:08+02:00 where my production system displays 2008-09-10T11:28:29+00:00 (mind the +00:00 and +02:00 at the end).
version.title: ActiveResource time changed

version.body:
Ok, so, my current workaround is: @@@ ruby def start attributes["start"] = attributes["start"] + Time.now.gmt_offset end @@@ in my model.
I realized, while using the rails console, the server which gets the date from the DB displays @@@ console start: 2008-09-10 11:48:00 @@@ while the server which gets the date from ARes displays @@@ console start: 2008-09-10 09:48:00 Z @@@
The timezone in the dev-system says its GMT+1 in Daylight Savings Time while the production-system says UTC
version.body-html:
Ok, so, my current workaround is:


def start
  attributes["start"] = attributes["start"] + Time.now.gmt_offset
end

in my model.

I realized, while using the rails console, the server which gets the date from the DB displays


start: 2008-09-10 11:48:00

while the server which gets the date from ARes displays


start: 2008-09-10 09:48:00 Z

The timezone in the dev-system says its GMT+1 in Daylight Savings Time while the production-system says UTC
version.title: ActiveResource time changed

version.body: There has been a whole bunch of time zone magic added in Rails 2.1, so you may want to consider upgrading to take advantage of this. [Geoff's article](http://mad.ly/2008/04/09/rails-21-time-zone-support-an-overview/) about this explains all the new improvements.
version.body-html: There has been a whole bunch of time zone magic added in Rails 2.1, so you may want to consider upgrading to take advantage of this. Geoff's article about this explains all the new improvements.
version.title: ActiveResource time changed

version.body: The times returned from the controller should be UTC by default, unless you are setting `Time.zone` / `config.time_zone` to something else.
version.body-html: The times returned from the controller should be UTC by default, unless you are setting Time.zone / config.time_zone to something else.
version.title: ActiveResource time changed

version.body:
This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has not been commented on for at least three months.
The resources of the Rails core team are limited, and so we are asking for your help. If you can still reproduce this error on the 3-0-stable branch or on master, please reply with all of the information you have about it and add "[state:open]" to your comment. This will reopen the ticket for review. Likewise, if you feel that this is a very important feature for Rails to include, please reply with your explanation so we can consider it.
Thank you for all your contributions, and we hope you will understand this step to focus our efforts where they are most helpful.
version.body-html:
This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has not been commented on for at least three months.

The resources of the Rails core team are limited, and so we are asking for your help. If you can still reproduce this error on the 3-0-stable branch or on master, please reply with all of the information you have about it and add "[state:open]" to your comment. This will reopen the ticket for review. Likewise, if you feel that this is a very important feature for Rails to include, please reply with your explanation so we can consider it.

Thank you for all your contributions, and we hope you will understand this step to focus our efforts where they are most helpful.
version.title: ActiveResource time changed
